borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions:
<p>The
proposal, by reason of siting, mass, scale, bulk and design, would be an
undesirable addition which would
not appear subservient to the original dwelling, would close off a characteristic gap between terraces and would present an incohesive roofscape. As such, it fails to respect or reflect the character of the original
dwelling, the terrace row of which it forms a part, and the surrounding area,
causing harm to each of these as well as to the street scene along both Gerald Road and Fordyke Road.&nbsp; In addition, the proposal would have an unacceptable impact on the historic character of the Becontree Estate. The proposal thus fails to accord with the
following policies which seek to ensure development recognises local character and promotes good design
whilst protecting and enhancing historic environments:
</p><ul><li>Paragraph 131, 135, 195, and 209 of the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2023)
</li><li> Policies D4 and HC1 of
     the London Plan (March 2021)
</li><li> Policies
     CP2 and CP3 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy
     (July 2010)
</li><li> Policies BP8
     and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide
     Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)
</li><li>Paragraph 5.3 and 5.4 of the Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary
     Planning Document (February 2012)
</li><li> Policies
     SP2, DMD1, DMD4 and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft
     Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)
</li></ul>

<p>The proposal, by reason of siting, scale and design,
would be an undesirable addition which would cause unacceptable loss of daylight, sunlight, outlook and privacy to neighbouring
dwellings. This would result in a harmful impact to the amenity currently
enjoyed by neighbouring occupiers. As such, the proposal fails to protect residential
amenity and constitutes un-neighbourly development. The proposal thus fails to
accord with the following policies which seek to ensure that development
proposals protect residential amenity:
</p><ul><li>Paragraph 135(f) of the National Planning Policy Framework
     (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2023)
</li><li>Policy D6 of the London Plan (March 2021)</li><li>Policies&nbsp;BP8 and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development
     Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)
</li><li>Paragraph 4.2, 5.3, and 5.4 of the Residential Extensions and
     Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)
</li><li> Policies DMD1 and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking
     and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version,
     December 2021)
</li></ul>
description: Construction of a two storey side extension and a part single storey part two storey rear extension
